attachments.title: ELI5: What does Square’s Flow library do?
attachments.text: Flow (or my fork of it, Flowless) is a backstack. Well, technically it is a thing that holds the backstack, which is called History.
attachments.fallback: Hacker Noon: ELI5: What does Square’s Flow library do?

text: it's partly about mine
the TL;DR is that Flow is a backstack manager
you can do typically either `goBack()` , `set()` or `setHistory()` operations
and that's pretty much the primary thing about it

I'm actually looking for something
Is the github repo upto date?
I've got a small problem with my flow currently
So I've got a checkout activity
Where once the user presses "Pay online" he'll get redirected if no payment "link" has been created
Then he'll get redirected back via a deep link
Off the top of my head, I think I use singleInstance (don't have AS open atm) so that when it comes back, all of the variables are still available
<@U3E2EEX38> <https://github.com/Zhuinden/simple-stack-demo> <-- this? yeah just pushed
The problem with this
When someone backs out during that process
thanks got it
He closes the app when he presses the back button the next time in the app
And when he opens the app again, he's at the previous activity
So at the pickup time selection screen :stuck_out_tongue:
I could perhaps just save the time temporarily
And avoid the whole situation
But I was wondering whether there weren't any more straightforward solutions
So just a "Flow": A -> B -> Different app -> B -> A

<https://github.com/Zhuinden/simple-stack-demo/blob/master/demo-stack/src/main/java/com/zhuinden/simplestackdemo/stack/Backstack.java#L66-L80> <-- this was a bitch to figure out
had there not been Flow's tests, this would have taken a while to find
if I don't block the bootstrap traversal if you initialize the backstack with something *before* you call `setStateChanger()`, then the "initial value" overwrites the history set previously
it was a really stupid bug and I don't know why i didn't think of it, hah

<@U3T0TAU07|jb> has joined the channel
<@U3SCYLNBE|kanand90> has joined the channel
<@U3E2EEX38> oh i figured it out
Flow *does* queue the operations, but in a not so obvious way
it's because the thing they queue has an abstract method and that's where they define the operation itself
